Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit comprising an inductor \(L\), capacitor \(C\), and resistor \(R\), governing the charge \(Q\) on the capacitor. The dynamics of \(Q\) are described by the second-order differential equation \(L \ddot{Q} + R \dot{Q} + \frac{Q}{C} = 0\). We examine the effect of a sinusoidal voltage source \(V(t) = V_0 \sin(\omega t)\) introduced into the circuit at different times.

Given the observed charge \(Q(T)\) at time \(T\), can we determine exactly whether a resistance change occurred at a prior time \(t_1\), and if \(V(t)\) was applied at \(t = 0\)?
Explanation: Multiple combinations of initial conditions, variations in resistance, and timings of external voltage application can yield the same observed charge \(Q(T)\). The overlap in potential charge trajectories and responses due to parameter changes and external forcing creates ambiguity in identifying specific interventions and initial conditions.
